thag21.1:32.2: The idea of the seven seers, long proverbial in Vedic culture, was adapted for Gotama in DN 14, where he is the seventh recorded Buddha in the lineage starting with Vipassī. Various texts and commentaries also allow the sense, “best of seers”.
thag21.1:32.4: In a cold northern climate this sounds unappealing, but in the heat the generous rain is a cool blessing.
thag21.1:34.1: The “wrong path” (ummagga) is one that takes you to the wrong destination (MN 107:14.26).
thag21.1:34.2: SN 8.8:8.2 has the second person carasi, and it seems reasonable to assume that Vaṅgīsa is continuing to address the Buddha directly. | From the same place accept the reading khila rather than khīla.
thag21.1:34.3: Here Vaṅgīsa turns to address the monks directly.
thag21.1:34.4: For asitaṁ bhāgaso pavibhajaṁ, compare the similar phrase vibhatto bhāgaso mito, which refers to the neatly ordered sections of hell (MN 130:16.4) or the suburbs (Snp 2.7:23.2). Vaṅgīsa is referring to the Buddha’s skill in breaking down complex or obscure matters and presenting them systematically.
thag21.1:35.3: These lines follow Bodhi’s reading at SN 8.8:9.3.
thag21.1:36.2: Ṭhiti is viññāṇaṭṭhiti (“planes of consciousness”), i.e. seven realms in which consciousness can be reborn (AN 7.44, DN 15:33.1, DN 33:1.8.11). This is a subtle allusion to the Buddha’s practice under his former teacher Āḷāra Kālāma, where he learned up to the highest “plane of consciousness”, namely the dimension of nothingness. In Snp 5.15:3.1 he speaks of how he understood that attainment and went beyond it. | Not to be confused with the four “grounds for consciousness”, i.e. the first four aggregates, as insight does not consist in going beyond these to consciousness (DN 33:1.11.122, SN 22.54:1.11).
thag21.1:36.4: Vaṅgīsa continues to invoke the Buddha’s life story by alluding to the first teaching, Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma (SN 56.11). After leaving behind those who taught rebirth in the “planes of consciousness”, the Buddha realized Awakening and proceeded to Varanasi to teach the group of five. This anticipates the next verses, which feature one of the five.
thag21.1:38.1: Spoken at SN 8.9:3.1, while the first two lines are included in Koṇḍañña’s verses at Thag 21.1:38.1.
thag21.1:38.2: Koṇḍañña was the first person to realize the Dhamma after the Buddha (SN 56.11:14.3). He features rarely in the early texts, but the Buddha once saw him meditating (Ud 7.6), and praised him as the senior mendicant (AN 1.188:1.1).
thag21.1:43.1: Emend anekākārasampannaṁ to anekākārasampannā per Bodhi’s Connected Discourses, note 527.
thag21.1:45.1: This verse is plural, presumably referring to a troupe of wandering bards. | For “drunk on poetry” see SN 4.13:2.1 and note.
thag21.1:63.3: Kāmakāro: “wish-granter”. Ordinary people cannot simply get what they want.
thag21.1:63.4: Saṅkheyyakāro: “comprehensibility-granter”. Saṅkheyya is “calculable, comprehensible”, not “after comprehension”. The Buddha has a gift for explaining things in a way that makes them comprehensible.
